utterances: I'm fine.

My question is: how long will it take the Republicans to decide - or maybe they're already on the road to deciding this - that the president is enough of an albatross around their neck, he doesn't have to run again in 2008, that they're just willing to dump him and his policies and start moving forward and taking care of their own interest?

Well, they still, you know, want to dump his money-raising abilities and, of course, all these senators who've been, and House members, who have been critical of the president on the war, on Alberto Gonzales, on the immigration bill, when President Bush comes to their district or states for a fundraiser they welcome him with open arms, perhaps they'd rather not have it with cameras there.
But again, so here is a mixed, sort of - unlike Ronald Reagan in 1988, who left office very, very popular, Bush's numbers are really, really low down.

And if the Republican Party is to avoid the kind of a year that they had in 2006 and 2008, they're going to have do what we saw in the presidential debate, basically, more and more candidates distancing themselves from the president.
Well, is he actually still able to bring in large amounts of cash for them?
And if so, why?
Well, he's still the president of the United States, and as soon - you know, he still remains popular with the Republican base.
I mean, 75 percent.
Some polls show that 75 percent of the Republicans still support the president, still support his conduct of the war, support the surge, things like that.
But ultimately, in a general election, when you throw in independents and Democrats, that support disappears completely.
Well, is that Republican base shrinking at the same time?
It is.

And that's why you'll find that if you look at the money raised by their candidates - the presidential candidates who've been raising money, every cycle, until now, it was the Republicans who always raise the most money.

You'll see it at the end of the month once again, as we saw the in last quarter, that it is the Democratic candidates who are raising the most money, having the most donors, and raising the most enthusiasm.
Elvis, thanks very much for the call.
Okay.
Now, let's retreat from presidential politics and get back to the business of pork for a little bit.
And there's a story out of Florida reported in the New York Times last week, about a $10 million earmark for a new roadway near Fort Myers courtesy of an Alaska congressman.
The Naples Daily News first reported what is basically a case of political you-scratch-my-back-I'll-scratch-yours two years ago.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's correct.
Basically, the developer wants to build homes, but there's not really a road to reach his home and he needs an interchange on the Interstate 75.

The congressman came in town and, I guess, they had a little fundraiser for them and raised some money for them, and next thing you know we have an earmark for this interchange, a study that could be done on this interchange.
And the curious thing is this congressman is not anybody from Florida, not somebody from that district, but Don Young of Alaska.
That's right.
Actually, the congressman from our district won't even claim that he had anything to do with getting this money for us.
What a miracle, he said, Connie Mack Jr.
That's correct.
That's correct.
Kind of a strange thing.
Now, what is this $10 million actually for?
It's for a study of the interchange on Interstate 75 at Coconut Road.
And basically, if the - it just covers the study.
There's actually - if we decide to build the interchange it would take another $100 million or so, which we don't even have.
Mm-hmm.
And there are county officials involved in all of these too.
They need to approve various spending elements.
And well, there have been elections in Florida over the past two years; the county commission has changed.
That's right.
The county commission has changed.
And this issue does not seem to die, so every time there's a meeting of transportation officials this subject comes up and they keep talking about it.
And in fact, they're going to talk about it again on Friday.
Mm-hmm.

Are the prospects - and we should point out that some say that constructing this interchange and more traffic on this road and the development there would hurt wetlands and other environmental - environmentally sensitive areas?
That's correct.
The opposition believes it could have seriously damaging effects on the environment to the East where this developer would like to build about 4,000 to 8,000 homes.
Now, you reported first on this two years ago, so a lot of water has gone under the bridge and a lot of traffic has not flowed on that - off the interchange?
That's right.
But still they're - they still are talking about it after two years and they still - there are still big mysteries since we have never gotten Don Young to speak to us about this.
So you've presumably kept pestering him for some time, for some illumination as to why he's so interested in this particular interchange in Florida.
That's correct.
He's now calling it a recycled story that has no legs.
And what about the developer?
How much money did he end up giving to Don Young?
Well, that - we believe he gave about a thousand dollars, but I mean, over the course, he's family has donated, I believe, $200,000 in the '06 election cycle.
And - then the Times reported on this story last week, you must have a little startled to open your paper there when he got to the office?
That's right.
We're all a little bit surprised that the Times had decided to put this on their front page.
Anything happening with the story to justify - well, this is the journalistic equivalent of getting Bigfooted, I think.
That's right.
It's quite flattering, actually.
Anything going - did you ask if there's anything going on?
Yeah.
More with it?
Yeah.
They are going to talk about it Friday.
And we may see it - the whole thing being nixed.
But actually, it looks like it may move forward.

They're at this crossroads where they're like, should we accept $10 million and do a study of this thing or should we turn down this, you know, free money essentially, and, you know, stick up our noses at the powers that be in Washington.
And let me ask you, Ken Rudin.
The story of - well, going down out of state for some fundraiser and coming back and proposing an earmark, is this unusual?
I'm not sure if it's unusual.

Only the fact that Don Young, at the time, was the chairman of the Appropriations Committee and he was getting tons of tons of contributions from all over the country, from interests all over the country.

But what's interesting is: one, it will be interesting to see what -how powerful Don Young is now, that he's in the minority; but two, there's also a political scandal going on, a bribery scandal going on in Alaska that could affect the dominant Republican Party that's been dominant for so many decades in that state.
Ted Stevens' son is under investigation for a separate bribery investigation.
Ted Stevens himself, his relationship with an oil company executive who may have done some work on his home.
I mean, these people are god.
Don Young has been a Congressman since '73.
Ted Stevens since '68.
They've been there forever.
And yet something seems to be changing in Alaska that may change the politics of the state.
And maybe they want to move from Florida and run from there?
There is a breeze that will take them there.
Could.
Julio Ochoa, thanks very much for being with us.
Congratulations, buddy.
It's been an honor.
Julio Ochoa, staff writer for the Naples Daily News in Florida.
Ken Ruding is also with us here in Studio 3A.
It's the Political Junkie.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's see if we can get some listeners on the line.
And let's go to - this is Mike(ph).
Mike, with us from San Leandro in California.
Hey.
Hey.
Good morning.
And thanks for the opportunity.
Sure.
